title: north-berwick-pipe-band-enjoy-taking-part-folklore-festival-germany
story: The festival was held in the Spree-Neisse district in the east of the country between June  and June .The band performed a iety of Highland dance and traditional Scottish music to audiences across three towns.They were joined by dancers from the Dunedin Dance Academy.Other acts at the festival included fellow musicians and dancers from countries such as Belarus, Poland, Belgium, India and Nepal.In light of their recent performance, the band are now preparing for upcoming events.First is their public show, which takes place every Wednesday evening in the Lodge Grounds during July and August. These performances are free to attend and begin at .pm.On Saturday they are leading the parade for North Berwick Leboat Fete, then on August  they are taking part in the North Berwick Highland Games and parade.The band are holding open practices on Monday evenings at .pm during July and August. These take place in St Andrew Blackadder Church Hall and are open to everyone of all ages.Visit northberwickpipeband or phone pipe major Eddie McFadzean on   for more information.

title: lighting-project-complete-historic-st-mary-39-s-parish-church
story: Substantial work was carried out at St Maryrsquos Parish Church over the first six months of the year to install a modern lighting system.A total of pound, has been spent on the scheme, which was completed last month.Stewart Meikle, an elder at the historic Haddington church, said the new lighting system was already making a massive dference.He said: ldquoThat is the project complete.ldquoThe benefits are ious: the interior of the building has been transformed, with the lighting highlighting all the features, the archways, the ceiling etc. We are also saving a lot of energy and making it easier to maintain.The improvements have been in the planning for several years. Mr Meikle paid tribute to AB Lighting and Nicholson Bros for their input in making the project a reality.Funding has come from a iety of sources.Mr Meikle told the Courier: ldquoIt has come from a mix of the churchrsquos own money from the sale of the manse, some of that has been allocated.ldquoThere was a lot of local fundraising held, including an art exhibition, and we have had personal donations from a fair few people.ldquoWe had grant applications from Viridor, WREN are providing money, and Tyne Esk LEADER are pitching in. There were ious small grants from Persimmon and Tesco Bags of Help.Work started in January, with the scheme split into two phases, which limited entry and exit from the church.Mr Meikle said the plan had been to get the work carried out in the first half of the year to ensure the building was looking at its best for the Lammermuir Festival, which takes place in September, and Armistice Day in November.He added: ldquoIt is pretty impressive.ldquoWe have had only a positive reaction from people in the church.ldquoLammermuir Festival are delighted with the lighting and we have not had anyone say a bad word about it.The Very Rev Dr John Cairns, interim moderator at St Maryrsquos, also paid tribute to all those involved.He said: ldquoMany congratulations to all the team who have seen this through to completion, from the contractors to our own property and finance folk.ldquoAbove all, a particular debt is owed to Stewart Meikle, for without his commitment and drive it would not have been achieved so effectively and timeously.ldquoThe lighting scheme was an ambition of [former minister, the late] Jenner Macrae and, like so much  she gave in her ministry, provides us with a heritage and a firm base from which to move into the next phase of St Maryrsquos le.

title: housebuilder-told-apologise-ormiston-residents
story: The housing firm was hauled before East Lothian Councils planning committee after it was discovered they had created a new access and put a sales caravan in place on the Limeylands site, in Ormiston, without seeking approval.And despite making a public apology for the move, councillors refused to give the changes planning permission instead rejecting a retrospective application and giving them two months to remove it.Councillors criticised Barratt for failing to engage with the local community and creating a feeling within local residents that there was a "lack of respect" for them.They were also told a sub contractor employed by the firm had mistakenly chopped down a mature tree which had not been in their plans causing further upset in the village.Councillor Willie Innes told the housebuilders that while he believed their actions were "misadventure" rather than "malicious" they could not be allowed to go unnoticed.And he warned the firm the situation in the village was "really a mess".Residents in Ormiston had opposed the plans to build  homes at the site off Limeylands Road, when they were first put forward five years ago.East Lothian Council rejected the original plans but the housing firm took their case to the Scottish Government Report who overturned the decision allowing them to go ahead with the housing.The planning committee were told that Barratt had now created a car park and sales caravan at the site with an access from the road, none of which were included in the approved plans.Mr Innes said: "What Barratt needs to understand is that they are creating a feeling in the commuity that Barratt does not respect them."The commuity opposed the original application and Barratt are holding it against them."I do not think that is the case, I think it is misadventure rather than malice. Barratt need to get round the table with the community."Jason Watt, from Barratt, told the committee that the company apologised for any concerns it has caused and was looking into improving its communication with the local community councily.He said the access created for the sales caravan was temporary and only in place while construction of the first home was carried out for health and safety reasons.However Mr Innes urged fellow committee members to reject a application approving the changes made saying Barratt needed to go back to the community and "rebuild its relationship" with them.The committee voted to reject the application by six votes to four.

title: craft-show-slot-joy-talented-jeweller-hannah-scott
story: Jeweller Hannah Scott will join  others in Edinburgh between next Fridayand August  to showcase her work.The second floor of White Stuff on the Capitalrsquos George Street will play home to a iety of craft and design pieces all made in Scotland, from cushions and textiles to jewellery, ceramics and glass.Hannah grew up near the beach in Cornwall but now lives in Musselburgh.She graduated from the Royal College of Art and Glasgow School of Art.She gathers inspiration for her work through maps, cityscapes and textures of the shoreline.Her most recent lsquoCoastline Collectionrsquo allows people to tell their own stories and capture their memories.Also on offer at the Craft Scotland Summer Show are maker-led workshops, which include hand weaving, willow weaving and paper folding.August  will see people being shown traditional bookbinding, while six days later, on August , attendees can learn how to create colour, pattern and textures on fabrics.Children aged  to  can get involved in young maker workshops, a new element for .Irene Kernan, Craft Scotland director, said: ldquoAt Craft Scotland we are incredibly privileged to be surrounded by beautul craft and engage with talented makers on a daily basis.ldquoKnowing the wealth of amazing work being made in Scotland, wersquore excited to be able to share so much of that at this yearrsquos show.ldquoWith the largest number of makers ever taking part this year,the Summer Show is the best place to see whatrsquos fresh and new in contemporary craft and the best place to discover new talents who are exploring interesting materials and themes.ldquoItrsquos particularly encouraging to see so many makers who will show their work with us for the first time.The Craft Scotland Summer Show is free to enter more information can be found at craftscotland.org

title: cash-boost-musselburgh-preston-lodge-rugby-clubs
story: Cash boost for two county rugby clubsRoyal Bank Rugby Force  SA :Cash boost for two county rugby clubsRoyal Bank Rugby Force  SA :The nationwide rugby programme launched by the bank in association with Scottish Rugby supports community clubs with funding each year to help them show off their passion for the game.Musselburgh RFC and Preston Lodge RFC will receive their prizes ahead of Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend, which kicks off on Saturday, August , when clubs across the country will host a range of events as they launch the new season.Malcolm Buchanan, chair, Scotland Board, Royal Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to award Musselburgh RFC and Preston Lodge RFC lsquoChampion Clubrsquo status in this yearrsquos Royal Bank RugbyForce programme.ldquo is set to be a thrilling year for Scottish rugby and we want to help make sure that our grassroots clubs across the country can benefit too.More than  clubs applied for Royal Bank RugbyForce support this year, and an official  of judges picked winners that demonstrated detailed and creative plans for their RugbyForce Weekend events that proudly show off their passion for the game.For , the campaign also focuses on helping clubs to make it easier for people to be part of a rugby community.Mr Buchanan said: ldquoThe standard of applications has been higher than ever and wersquore very proud to be able to provide funding and support for some truly fantastic community rugby projects across the country.ldquoRoyal Bank of Scotland has a long-standing commitment to rugby in Scotland. Over the  years which Royal Bank RugbyForce has been running, we have witnessed at first-hand the huge dference the programme has made to clubs, their members and the communities in which they play.ldquoWe would like to encourage everyone from club members to those thinking about getting involved in rugby to head to their local club for Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend and become part of the rugby community.The nationwide programme supports clubs by providing funding to help them attract new members, make improvements to facilities and become more sustainable. With financial and practical support from the Royal Bank and professional advice from Scottish Rugby representatives, including Scotland and Glasgow Warriors legend Al Kellock, the programme has helped to deliver a range of benefits to clubs, including coaching clinics, boosting player numbers, attracting sponsorship and making pitch improvements.

title: income-boost-call-centre-dealing-non-east-lothian-calls
story: The council raised nearly pound, last year by providing services to outside agencies including its neighbours and is one of only two councils in Scotland which provides services for three local authorities at its centre for additional income.A report on the number of calls covered revealed that the contact centre dealt with , calls for Scottish Borders Council in its first year of providing call services for them.It also handled almost as many out of hours calls for Midlothian Council last year ndash , ndash than it did for East Lothian residents, who called the out of hours line , times.The centre reported receiving more than , service calls during the last financial year, with , for neighbouring authorities.An additional , calls were dealt with through its switchboard.In a report to the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee, it was revealed an additional five full-time workers were taken on by the community response team to deal with calls from the Scottish Borders.Eileen Morrison, head of customer services, said that funding from Scottish Borders covered the funding of additional staff and provided additional cash for the council.Councillors were told that taking on the contract had been a benefit to the centre, which has provided out of hours services for Midlothian Council for nearly a decade and also services for Castle Rock Edin and East Lothian Housing Association for additional income.Raymond McGill, contact centre manager, said: ldquoBy having a larger team everybody benefits. It is a strong and better service because we have been able to expand in this way.The report revealed services provided to Scottish Borders Council included community alarm and telecare calls and out of hours emergency services for social work and council repairs.And it revealed that the contact centre, which is based in Penston House, Macmerry, has also introduced an Election Line in recent years to deal with ldquomany election referendum calls in the run-up to an election.It was reported that  per cent of calls to the centre were answered or received call backs, slightly down from . per cent the previous year but still above the  per cent target. They had also experienced a dip in the number of calls answeredwithin  seconds, which fellto just under  per cent.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe total received from all parties for the services we provide on their behalf was almost pound, for  . This has enabled us to continue to invest in the services that we provide to our own residents through the contact centre.ldquoOur council is committed to working in new ways within the challenging financial climate.

title: funding-boost-charities-supporting-children-families
story: East Lothian Council has announced funding for eight third-sector organisations that work with children and young people.It has also set aside a further pound, to fund stays at a respite centre run by Aberlour Child Care Trust.A report by the councilrsquos head of children services revealed that money which had in the past been awarded to Aberlour directly in a single payment was now being set aside in a budget to pay for stays at Bankfoot Respite Centre, Prestonpans, on a case by case basis.The funding remains committed to the centre and will be overseen by the councilrsquos disability teamrsquos budget.Among the organisations receiving part of over pound, in grant funding is East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme, which received just over pound, to help it run respite day schemes during the school holidays in the coming year, while a further pound, has been awarded to Childrenst to support its kinship care and family support work.Action for Children, which also provides residential short breaks to give parents and carers of children and young people with severe and complex needs respite, received a grant of pound,.Home-Start East Lothian, which provides volunteer support to families with children under five in their homes, has been awarded just over pound,, and Cyrenians ConflictResolution Services, which works to keep young people in the family home, received pound,.An additional grant of pound, was given to ChildrenrsquosHospices Across Scotland .

title: morning-blues-county-rail-commuters-edinburgh-bound-line-blocked
story: North Berwick line services could not get to Waverley because the Edinburgh to London Sleeper had broken down near the capitals Abbeyhill area.Replacement bus services were put on by Scotrail but some rail users have complained that some buses were late or did not turn up at all.Scotrail announced on social media at about am that the Sleeper had been moved and that service wouldto normal from about am.

title: musselburgh-neighbours-scoop-30-000-thanks-postcode
story: The Stoneyhill Crescent neighbours netted the windfall when EH TD was announced as a winner with Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery on Tuesday.The prize was won as part of a special summer campaign where a lucky postcode will be announced as a winner of the poundK prize every day. All the players in that postcode then pick up a cheque worth poundK for every ticket that they play with.The duo were the only people playing with the winning postcode, and chose to remain anonymous, but had any of their neighbours been playing then they too would have picked up a cheque for pound,.Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery ambassador Matt Johnson sent his congratulations, saying: ldquoI couldnrsquot be more thrilled for the lucky Musselburgh pair picking up a prize today.ldquoI was lucky enough to spend the day in the town and got to enjoy an ice cream from the famous Lucarsquos, as well as visit Newhailes House, which is just minutes along the road from our winners and run by National Trust for Scotland - an organisation thatrsquos been awarded pound, in funding raised by players.ldquoWith Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery good causes win too and itrsquos great to see that, no matter where you go in the country, yoursquore never far from an organisation thatrsquos benefitted from the support of our players.With a minimum of  per cent from ticket sales going directly to charities, players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery have raised more than pound million to date for thousands of projects across Great Britain and internationally.This draw was promoted on behalf of Depaul which has received over pound. million thanks to player support.This funding is enabling the charity to tackle both the immediate and long-term effects of homelessness, helping it provide safe and stable futures for people who get left behind by society.For more information on Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery visit www.postcodelottery or Facebook and Twitter.

title: st-mary-39-s-parish-church-set-welcome-new-minister
story: The Rev Alison McDonald takes over the reins at St Maryrsquos Parish Church this eveningfollowing a unanimous vote of the churchrsquos congregation when she preached as sole nominee.Ms McDonaldrsquos induction takes place today before she is preached in by the Very Rev Dr Sheilagh Kesting on Sunday.She said: ldquoWhen I met the nominating committee, I was impressed by their vision to be an even greater positive force at the heart of the community. I am excited by all the creative possibilities of worship in the beautul church building.ldquoI am looking forward to progressing some of the ideas that the congregation have for the space, and to working in partnership across the town.ldquoWhen I preached as sole nominee, the people of St Maryrsquos couldnrsquot have been more genuine, warm, welcoming and friendly.ldquoI felt that they were looking forward to me beginning ministry with them as much as I am looking forward to becoming their minister.Originally from Dundee, Ms McDonald has been minister at Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, for more than  years.The -year-old said making the switch from Musselburgh was ldquoa wrench but she felt it was ldquotime to move.She said: ldquoIt has been a privilege to serve as minister of Northesk and in the communities of Fisherrow and Musselburgh. I am grateful for their love and support and thankful for the journey of faith that we have been on together over the years.St Maryrsquos has not had a permanent minister since the death last year of the Rev Jenner Macrae, who served the congregation for  years.Alison Meikle, session clerk, told the Courier: ldquoWe were delighted that Alison answered the call to be our minister. She has so much experience both as a parish minister and in the wider church.ldquoThings that struck a chord with us included her interest in working with families and across our growing community, her deep interest in music ndash which is so much part of worship at St Maryrsquos ndash and her commitment to ecumenical relations: St Maryrsquos works closely day-to-day with all our neighbouring churches.ldquoHer interests and ambitions fitted perfectly with ours.Ms McDonald was ordained in  in Budapest into a new post as Associate Minister at St Columbarsquos Church of Scotland and Mission Partner with the Reformed Church of Hungary.She ed to Scotland three years later, serving in Edinburgh before being called to Musselburgh in .Ms McDonald will be joined in Haddington by her husband, the Rev Sandy Horsburgh, who is minister of St Nicholas Buccleuch, Dalkeith, so that the manse of St Maryrsquos will also be the manse of St Nicholas Buccleuch.

title: adventurer-set-cross-australia-madagascar-run-across-iceland
story: But not this globetrotter. Despite clocking up more than , kilometres in ious challenges far too tasking for most ordinary humans, this itchy feet adventurer has set his sights on cycling and running across two of the worldrsquos biggest islands.For his latest solo challenge, Jamie is cycling from the south to the north of Australia before running theof Madagascar!The -year-old has only just finished running more than  kilometres across Iceland in less than a fortnight.He said: ldquoI am flying to Australia on August  and will be cycling , kilometres from Melbourne to Darwin up through the centre.ldquoThen, in November, I am flying to Madagascar to run , kilometres from north to south of the island.ldquoItrsquos a full-on year of adventuring!ldquoEvery time I look at a map I see a new adventure.ldquoI add them to the list and hopefully I find the time and funding to tick them off. The ultimate dream would be to swim the Atlantic. . . but thatrsquos a pipe dream at the moment!The trip to Iceland saw Jamie, from Whittingehame, run from the countryrsquos east to west coast in just  days after setting off on July .Clocking up about  kilometres a day, he had to contend with a range of obstacles ndash and only one hour of darkness a day.He said: ldquoThere were a number of big challenges including the remoteness of the F [the track that runs through the centre of Iceland], the weather which is cold, wet and windy, the weight of my backpack [about  kg] and the obvious challenge of running an ultra marathon distance day in and day out for  days.ldquoLuckily the  hours of daylight wasnrsquot too much of an issue. An eye mask normally helped and after running over  kilometres the body is ready to sleep.ldquoOn the plus side, I didnrsquot need a torch!Jamie slept on a blow-up mattress in a summer sleeping bag and bivi bag, under a tarpaulin.The former Belhaven Hill School, Stenton Primary School and Loretto School pupil caught the publicrsquos attention four years ago.He left his job at an international communications agency in London to run from Canadarsquos third largest city, Vancouver, to the capital of Argentina, Buenos Aires.The -month adventure raised more than pound, for CALM , Macmillan Cancer Support and WaterAid.Jamie iss busy putting pen to paper about the adventure, with more than , words already written.He told the Courier that writing the book was ldquoharder and more time consuming than the adventure itself.Since then, he has also scaled the highest mountain in the southern and western hemisphere ndash Aconcagua, in Argentina ndash and cycled from Sao Paulo, in Brazil, to Bolviarsquos La Paz. He has completed over , kilometres of adventuring over the last five years and visited  dferent countries.ldquoEven though my current adventures are as toughnot tougher than those in the past, people just assume I will successfully complete them, he said.ldquoI think I need to get better at making people realise what I am doing. But everyonersquos confidence in me helps me find the confidence in myself to perform.

title: student-play-key-role-developing-cycling-scotland
story: Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Louie Doig is one of nine who will represent the voice of young people in the sport.The , which is led by the sportrsquos governing body Scottish Cycling, aims to help influence and shape the future of Cycling in Scotland.It met for the first time at Scottish Cyclingrsquos headquarters at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow last month.Louie, who is about to start a degree in Sports Science at Glasgow University, has been part of Edinburgh Road Club since Summer , with his most recent success being a win in the Peebles CC Road Race earlier this year.He believes it is vital that Scottish Cycling has a  for young people to express their views.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to the opportunity of working with my fellow members to develop a range of new projects to get more people cycling across Scotland.The  will be engaged in projects across the organisation ndash from regional development to events, and coaching and education.Craig Burn, Scottish Cycling CEO, said: ldquoI look forward to seeing the positive impact their dedication and passion for cycling in Scotland has.

title: new-life-breathed-back-haddington-39-s-victoria-inn
story: The Victoria Inn, on the townrsquos Court Street, has been shut for about a year but work to improve and re-open the building is now under way.Craig Douglas, who has now leased the premises, has vowed to restore the venue to its former glory.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite aware it has been empty for a while and it was being run by a management company for a short period of time.ldquoI want to bring stability to the area and we have to instil a bit of confidence in the locals. We are here for a long time not just a quick fix.He described it as ldquoa gorgeous building in a gorgeous area and said it ldquohuge potential.Work at the building, which is also home to The Avenue restaurant, will be carried out over three stages. A bar refurbishment is taking place at the moment and the new bar should be open in the coming weeksThen, attention will turn to the restaurant, with Mr Douglas keen to see that up and running by ldquomid to late August.Finally, work will be carried out on the five rooms above the premises.Mr Douglas, who has been involved in the industry in Edinburgh and Spain for a number of years, expected the rooms might not be in use until after the summer tourist season.He said: ldquoIt has got the facilities for us to do nice fresh, gastropub, homemade food. We are going to try to source local produce.The premises were previously owned by Greene King, who also own Belhaven Brewery.Mr Douglas, , from Edinburgh, who also runs The Old Aberlady Inn, said: ldquoI remember years ago I used to play rugby and I remember coming down to play Haddington.The Victoria Inn used to be absolutely packed.ldquoIf my memory serves me right, you would struggle to get a seat in the place.I would like to bring that back to the area again.Councillor Craig Hoy, who lives in the town, was happy to hear the prominent building was being brought back into use.He said: ldquoIf we can strengthen Haddingtonrsquos reputation as a food and drink destination at the heart of East Lothian, which is renowned for its farming and food production, it is something we can really build on in East Lothian and beyond. title: fringe-sea-gullane-games-innerwick-flower-show-among-attractions-weekend
story: The Courierhas put together a list of five of the top things to do between this evening and over the weekend.Whether it is football or flowers, horses or celebrities ormuch more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Fringe by the SeaThe great and good of art, comedy and music are set to light up the countyrsquos coastline as North Berwickrsquos Fringe by the Sea festival launches today .Tonight, at pm, there is a chance to hear Newsnights Kirsty Wark discuss her new novel in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent.Later that evening, at pm, it is the turn of Fred MacAulay.The comedian and radio presenter will light up the stage with his comedy in the same venue.Meanwhile, in the towns community centre, NB Movies is showing Neither Wolf Nor Dog from pm.Tomorrow , former Masterchef winner, food writer and novelist Sue Lawrence visits the towns library.From pm, she will discuss her new novel Down to the Sea, which is set in Newhaven.Comedian Reginald D Hunter performs in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm while there is live music from The Cuban Brothers from pm in the same venue.Sunday brings Edinburgh-based author, speaker, blogger and podcaster JoJo Fraser to the Lighthouse Spiegeltent from pm.Then, at pm in the same venue, DJ Monski Mouse will be playing some hits specially for the under-fives and parents carers.American RB singer-songwriter Alexander ONeal will be in the Simpson and Marwick Spiegeltent from pm.There is plenty more on offer from todaythrough to August .For tickets, go to www.fringebythesea. Gullane GamesTHE curtain comes down on another memorable Gullane Games.This eveningfeatures a quiz night in the village hall for over-s.Tickets are pound for a team of four and available from gullanegames@outlookThe main event is Gullane Games Day itself tomorrow , plus parade.The parade under way at the childrenrsquos course at .pm.Fancy dress is optional and the theme of the parade is lsquoOur Natural Environmentrsquo.Prizes will be awarded for the best costume to age categories P and under, and P and above.The first race begins at .pm, while a tea tent, face painting, beat the goalie, assault course and tug of war are also on offer.Throughout the week, shops will be displaying lsquodeliberate mistakesrsquo in their windows for children to spot entry forms for the competition are available from the pharmacy on the opening day of the games.. title: rnli-crew-welcome-french-visitors
story: Keen swimmers Charlotte Bapao and Amelie Bobes have swapped the French village of Serres-Castet,  kilometres from Biarritz on Francersquos west coast, for a trip to Scotland.The exchange has come through Haddington and District Amateur Swimming Club, with the two youngsters visiting the RNLI to see the work that they do and to climb aboard the inshore leboat.Charlotte and Amelie, both , are members of the villagersquos swimming club, with exchange trips between the two swimming clubs dating back more than  years.More than  youngsters have enjoyed a -day stay with families throughout the county.Charlotte and Amelie have been staying with crew member Iain McDougall and family.A spokeswoman for Dunbar RNLI said: ldquoHis children, Jack, Katie and Robbie, joined the girls as fellow crew member Becs Miller told them all about the importance of staying safe in the water, while showing them the equipment we use and how our D-class inshore leboat helps us save lives at sea.

title: roadworks-close-one-main-routes-musselburgh
story: The B from Monktonhall Place to Musselburgh Services roundabout closes from midnight on Monday and is due to run until the end of August .The council said it has held extensive discussions with the contractor GTC, working on behalf of Persimmon Homes, to agree a -hour work programme that coordinates gas and power works to minimise disruption in the area.A council spokesperson said: "This closure is essential to put in place the utilities infrastructure required to support major new developments in the area."The contractor originally applied for a three week closure period."However our priority is to minimise disruption to residents and drivers so we have negotiated a -hour work programme that coordinates utility services to ensure this work is completed quickly and ahead of the schools ing."Diversion signs will be in place throughout the works. A copy of the road closure noticeis available online from www.tellmescotland.gov.ukFollowing discussions, Prentice Coaches has confirmed that it will operate the  service as normal to Tesco, then operate via Eskview Terrace, Monktonhall Terrace, Mayfield Crescent, Stoneybank Crescent, Whitehill Farm Road, QMU, Clayknowes Road to the Fort Kinnaird, the Wisp and Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.The council will arrange a free shuttle bus from Old Craighall to the ERI along the  service route. The shuttle bus will run as per the existing  timetable.Further work is planned from the service area roundabout on the B south west to the Midlothian boundary.Discussions are still ongoing with the contractor to agree traffic management for this section.Planning permission in principle was granted for a mixed use development at Old Craighall including , homes, a primary school, business space, community facilities, public parks and playing fields, an innovation hub for business and for other employment land.A separate application, also by Persimmon Homes, for detailed planning permission for  houses and  flats on the Old Craighall site was also approved at the meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos Planning Committee earlier this year.The application for the mixed use development at Old Craighall, as allocated in the Local Development Plan, was submitted following community consultation including a public event at The Brunton, Musselburgh.The total site is . hectares and refers to land around Queen Margaret Universityand Musselburgh railway station and to the north and south of the A.The plans include improvements to the junction off the A at QMU as well as the creation of pedestrian and cycle routes including the councilrsquos Segregated Active Travel Corridor.The Innovation Hub at QMT is part of the multi-million pound Edinburgh  South East Scotland City Region Deal, which will contribute to the joint development between East Lothian Council and QMU.The hub will facilitate an expansion of the universityrsquos existing Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation and will also provide flexible commercial space for small and medium sized businesses in the food and drink sector.Council officers had recommended granting of permission in principle for the two applications with conditions and a Section  agreement to fund transport infrastructure improvements, contributions for the new primary school and for secondary education provision and for community pitches.Planning committee members unanimously agreed to approve both applications.The permission granted for the first phase of housing on the Old Craighall site includes  affordable units.

title: objections-lodged-plans-rocket-engine-test-site
story: Scottish space company Skyrora has applied to East Lothian Council to occupy the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station coal handling plant for five years to build a temporary equipment test site.Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council hosted an event with representatives from Skyrora in attendance and raised some concerns that they had gathered both from within the community council and from the locals.Among the issues raised related to the results of the noise assessment that Skyrora had conducted on the surrounding area to measure the impact of the engine tests.The community council felt that not enough distinction was made between familiar noise and unfamiliar noise, with particular reference to the finding that bird song was the prevailing noise in the area.Also mentioned was the potential site traffic travelling on the B, past Cockenzie Primary School and therefore becoming disruptive, and lastly, that the security fencing planned for the site would not be high enough to guarantee that it will prevent unlawful access. Bryan Hickman, chairman of the community council, said: ldquoThe community council thank the representatives of Skyrora for meeting the community.ldquoMany questions were raised including the objections submitted by the community council and the others from the floor. In my opinion, the answers to some of the points raised were not clear or consistent with the planning documents submitted.ldquoThe consensus was that this development is not suitable for a site situated close to residential areas, schools and busy roads.Derek Harris, business operations manager at Skyrora, said: ldquoSuch is our commitment to keeping the local community up to speed on plans and taking their views into account, this was our fourth meeting in the town.ldquoThe test site offers East Lothian the opportunity to play an invaluable role in the infrastructure to support Scotlandrsquos existing space ambitions and inspire the next generation in the town to a career in STEM [science, technology, engineering, mathematics] while bringing a raft of economic opportunities to the town.Skyrora recently successfully tested their first D-printed commercial rocket engine at Newquay airport in Cornwall.

title: lunch-club-39-s-work-makes-national-television-news
story: The Pennypit-based Preston Seton Gosford Lunchclub were featured on the news to showcase the important work that groups like this do when dealing with holiday hunger for young children.Lorna Bellany, who has been manager of the lunch club for the past year, said: ldquoIt all happened very quickly, charity Children in Scotland organised it the night before, so it was a rush to get things ready.ldquoThe kids loved it. title: swallows-migration-inspiration-mural

title: letter-week-dont-let-racecourse-efforts-go-waste
story: That East Lothian Council was a major force for good and catalyst for the marvellous improvements made to the course over recent years is not up for debate, and it therefore genuinely saddens me we now find ourselves in the position we are today.However, whatever the rights and wrongs on both sides of the current management debate, it is to the future that efforts and a strategic vision for the course must now be concentrated.I had the pleasure of working with many hard-working and dedicated staff from both the council and the racecourse whose sole objectives were to keep improving the racecourse experience whilst making it the lsquofive-starrsquo attraction it is today.Any future management team should not forget this.To run and manage Musselburgh Racecourse is a privilege and with that privilege comes major responsibilities. Whoever is lucky enough to take on its running must first and foremost make Musselburgh Racecourse their priority.Too much time, effort and sheer hard work has been spent in recent years by the people of Musselburgh and East Lothian to see any future benefits generated by the track invested in other ventures other than Musselburgh Racecourse.To the new management team, when appointed, I wish them good luck but Irsquod also point out that their actions and commitments to the course will no doubt be closely followed by staff, owners and trainers, bookmakers, racegoers and annual members.We have a marvellous product at Musselburgh. title: Rosemary Goring  Judge society by how happy we are  not how wealthy
story: The merest glimpse of the lives of moguls, oligarchs and millionaires tells you that. Are the faces staring out from the pages of glossy magazines shining with wellbeing  They might be tanned, toned, and expensively exfoliated, butany of these iniduals has a heart full of joy, it is unlikely to be as a result of their lestyle.In a recent talk, Nicola Sturgeon made an appeal to commonsense, stating what, deep down, most of us already know. She claims that when calibrating a countryrsquos standing and success, gross domestic product is not the most accurate measure. Not least among the misleading factors when using GDP as a guide is that its figures ignore unpaid carersrsquo work, yet put a value on illegal drug consumption. Just as worryingly, says Ms Sturgeon, ldquoIt values activity in the short term that boosts the economy eventhat activity is hugely damaging to the sustainability of our planet in the longer term.The First Ministerrsquos laudable aspiration is that ldquothe objective of economic policy should be collective wellbeing ndash how happy and healthy a population is, not just how wealthy a population is. Hoping to establish a fairer and truer scale of assessment, she is collaborating with the prime ministers of New Zealand and Iceland ndash women all, in charge of countries geographically on the fringes, who are prepared to challenge convention.Cynics might, of course, say that Ms Sturgeon is simply laying the groundwork for another independence bid, in which those predicting dire financial consequences will be brushed off as old-fashioned and out of touch by placing too much emphasis on our economic prowess. Yet with Brexit, not just economists but rabid Leavers acknowledge that orce from the EU will cause financial shockwaves. Clearly, this is a risk they think worth running. By the same token, idealists north of the Border, who want us to exit from the UK, often say that the possibility of diminished economic performance after independence would not in itself be a deal breaker. There are bigger issues at stake.That argument is for another day. At this point, were Scotland to become a pioneer in putting a fairer society ahead of a more affluent one, this would represent nothing less than a second enlightenment. The inequalities in health and housing, education and attainment that are nakedly apparent all around us, are shaming for one of the wealthiest countries in the world. No matter how much those at the top make, or how vibrant our financial markets, poverty and desperate hardship for too many people persists. Itrsquos tempting to think that those who see GDP and similar indices as telling the whole story have also embraced the biblical creed that the poor will always be with us ndash in other words, there is nothing we can do about their plight.While the SNP has not been far-sighted or proactive enough to combat the recent shocking rise in drug-related deaths, many of them linked to deprivation and hopelessness, nevertheless Ms Sturgeon and the like-minded leaders with whom she is allied, have a strong social conscience. If the message that money is only part of the equation takes hold, it could potentially prove a turning point for the way all rich societies see, and regulate, themselves.Naturally therersquos a danger when writing disparagingly about high-income earners of appearing either green-eyed or preachy. Despite spending a childhood in the pews, hearing how the widowrsquos mite was as valuable as the millionairersquos cheque, and that those who are hard up today will be blessed with eternal treasures in the hereafter, I nevertheless know that no pair of rose-tinted spectacles can make a terrying bill, an unattainable holiday or too-expensive winter coat, one bit easier to bear. As Mae West put it bluntly: ldquoIrsquove been rich and Irsquove been poor, and rich is better.When it comes to wellbeing, you donrsquot need a carbon monoxide monitor to recognise that the air in Stornoway or St Abbs is far better for us than that in the throbbing financial hearts of Edinburgh or Glasgow, or for that matter Tokyo and New York. Wellbeing consists of something way beyond liquidity, location, or assets. Those in their gated communities, who store their Cartier watches in a vault, have cut themselves off from the rest of society. Is that really enviable  This is not to say they might not be really decent, kind-hearted people who give generously to good causes. Perhaps some of them are. But no matter how open-handed they appear to be, money creates a spiralling gulf between the haves and the have-nots, and sometimes cause rts much closer to home, as family lawyers will attest.Far from solving the problem by capitalistsrsquo pet theory of ldquotrickle-down, too much capital at the top of society actually entrenches inequality. Thus, the endless pursuit of higher incomes, pricier properties, competitive conspicuous consumption, whether at a personal or national level, is intrinsically unhealthy. Once you believe that the GDP graph should show an inexorable year-on-year increase, you become blinkered. This is as true, I suspect, for those running the country as for the inidual.Hunger for amassing hundreds of thousands of pounds, and the power that comes with it, is a recipe for potential disaster. It is psychologically and spiritually corrosive. Slowing the Gradgrind pursuit of ever-greater productivity, focusing on more nourishing and longer-lasting priorities, is a way of calling time on the fallacy that the bottom line is all that matters, and that cash is king. It is a way of taking an ethical stance, and saying enough is enough. How to calculate what constitutes enough, of course ndash be it income, savings, love, leisure, charity, you name it ndash is even harder than measuring happiness.Read more: Scotlands history has lain in the British shadow for too long

title: claire-mcvicar-lothian-buses-driving-seat-improve-air-quality

title: scotland-39-s-newest-party-leader-swaps-big-top-political-circus
story: When not working full-time as an engineer, Lorna Slater mdash the new co-leader of the Scottish Greens mdash can be found flying through the air on a trapeze.The -year-old even trained with Aerial Edge, Glasgowrsquos circus school, for four months last year.As she puts it: ldquoYou canrsquot worry about politics or work when yoursquore hanging upside down by one hand.:Revealed: Scottish Greens have lost % of their members since indyref riseMs Slater and long-standing MSP Patrick Harvie were elected co-leaders of the Scottish Greens last week, and will lead the party into the crucial  Holyrood polls.Both have put the climate emergency centre stage, while Brexit and independence also loom large.Speaking to The Herald following her election, Ms Slater outlined the balancing act of priorities the party now faces.And she also revealed her unusual way of letting off steam ndash sparked by flying trapeze lessons she was given for her th birthday.ldquoTo me the most important issue is the climate emergency, but unfortunately, with Brexit and all that, we have to swim in the waters that we find ourselves in, she said.ldquoSo we canrsquot ignore Brexit. Itrsquos whatrsquos on peoplersquos minds. I think wersquore going to have to try and ride both those horses ndash keep pressing on the climate emergency, keeping pushing the SNP Government to do more, because they declare a climate emergency and do nothing, and equally keep clear what our positive vision is for an independent Scotland in the EU.ldquoThe Unionist parties donrsquot have anything positive to say. Itrsquos all gloom and misery.ldquoThey tell this really miserable story about what the Union means post-Brexit, and I just donrsquot think you can win like that. You win by telling a positive story.An electromechanical engineer working in the renewable sector, Ms Slater was born in Canada and has previously been a Green candidate for Edinburgh Council and the European Parliament.She plans to stand for the Scottish Parliament and told activists she will be a ldquohands-on campaigner and organiser. Lothian MSP Alison Johnstone will continue to co-lead the Greens at Holyrood alongside Mr Harvie.:New Greens co-leader: SNP tie-up would be "terrible" ideaMs Slater said her primary goal is to help the Greens win more seats, with a particular focus on women and non-binary people.And she appeared keen to put clear green water between her party and the SNP.She dismissed suggestions the two parties should co-ordinate on independence in their next manestos, but made clear policies are for members to decide.She also rejected the idea of the Greens ndash who have propped up the last three budgets under the minority SNP administration ndash entering into any formal Holyrood coalition with the Nationalists in future.ldquoThe only issue we have in common with the SNP is independence, she said.ldquoOn everything , we tend to vote dferently from them. They vote with the Tories we vote with Labour.ldquoSo I think that that would actually be a terrible idea. It would be a terrible idea because we would end up signing up to policies that we donrsquot agree with at all.ldquoI think where we are right now is quite a good position to be in, where we can push the SNP on issues that matter to us, but we are not signed up to things that we really donrsquot agree with.Ms Slater said the SNP had failed ldquomiserably on land reform, and had left power ldquoin the hands of developers and big corporations and landowners.And she insisted the Nationalists ldquohave to finally pull their finger out on council tax.She added: ldquoThey have promised in manesto after manesto to reform it, and they keep not doing it. This is a very regressive tax. It would make a huge dference to public services.ldquoThey canrsquot keep complaining that Westminster is imposing this austerity on us when they themselves are not bold enough to reform that council tax.ldquoSo, for me, thatrsquos really important. As is taking action on this climate emergency that theyrsquove declared, and then havenrsquot done anything about.ldquoThey cannot continue to support grouse shooting and the fossil fuel industry and expanding the roads and so on. If therersquos a climate emergency, either there is or there isnrsquot.Asked about her passions outside of politics, Ms Slater revealed she trains with the circus, developing her skills on the flying trapeze and aerial silks. ldquoItrsquos just a hobby, she said, sparked by that gt almost four years ago.Still, with the new Scottish Green leaders elected for a two-year term, during a period of unprecedented political upheaval, there will be a lot to juggle. Circus skills could come in handy.

title: splits-indyref2-set-hamper-bid-halt-hard-brexit
story: The Peoplersquos Vote campaign, which wants a second EU referendum vote with Remain as an option, has already identied the ldquopolarising issue as a potential obstacle in a snap election.It emerged yesterday that the campaign will target about  marginal seatsMPs force Prime Minister Boris Johnson to go to the country by October .Campaigners said they would pour resources into about  seats to help remove no-deal MPs and into about  more to defend Remain MPs vulnerable to a challenge.South of the Border, the plan would focus on persuading Labour supporters to vote LibDem and vice versa, according to which party had the best chance of success.:SNP Health Secretary could have to resign over hospital scandal, says trade unionistIn Scotland, the Conservatives would be defending  seats, nine with majorities below ,, all won by the SNP in  but several held by the LibDems before then.They include Stirling, the UKrsquos third most marginal Tory seat, where Stephen Kerrrsquos majority is .The SNPrsquos Pete Wishart would be trying to fend off a Conservative challenge in Perth  NorthPerthshire after his majority was cut to just  in .In the Brecon  Radnorshire by-election last week, a tactical voting pact by Remain parties helped the LibDems win the Tory seat, while the Brexit Party split the Leave vote.The LibDemsrsquo gain reduced Mr Johnsonrsquos parliamentary majority to one, increasing speculation about an early election to overcome the Westminster impasse on Brexit.However, the independence issue could thwart any similar pact in Scotland because the Tories would play the Unionist card.A source at the Peoplersquos Vote campaign said: ldquoScotland is dficult because we need to be sure thatwe polarise the contest between the Tories and the SNP it delivers the results the campaign wants.ldquoThat is, it sees the Tories defeated rather than letting them present themselves as the best-placed Unionist candidate to defeat the SNP. So we need to research and test further on this.ldquoThere isnrsquot the same issue in Wales because the independence debate is not so polarising.ldquoBut we will be pragmatic and take soundings from our supporters in all parties on this.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is due to give her thoughts on the developing situation in an appearance at the Edinburgh fringe today with the LBC presenter and political commentator Iain Dale. Mr Johnson added to speculation about an election by announcing a one-off pound. billion boost for NHS England yesterday ndash money critics dismissed as derisory, given its repairs backlog.The cash will result in pound million extra cash for Scotland via the Barnett formula.Mr Johnson also said NHS pensions would be reformed to end the UK-wide problem of consultants cutting back their hours ndash adding to waiting times ndash to avoid pension-related tax bills.An alliance to oust Tory MPs would threaten Ruth Davidsonrsquos leadership of the Scottish Tories, as it could wipe out most of the gains her party made in .But tribal isions among Remain parties are working in her favour.:New Greens co-leader: SNP tie-up would be "terrible" ideaOn Saturday, Orkney  Shetland MP Alastair Carmichael, the LibDem whip at Westminster, was asked by the BBChis party would step aside for SNP candidates in a Remain alliance.He said: ldquoNo we wouldnrsquot and for one very simple reason: the SNP are one side of another fundamental nationalist argument which is about Scottish independence. So no, we wouldnrsquot be able to work with them.The SNP seized on the comment to hark back to Jo Swinson serving as a minister in the Tory-LibDem Coalition.MP Neil Gray said: ldquoJo Swinson is showing her true colours and proving yet again that the LibDems simply cannot be trusted by completely ruling out working with us but keeping the door open to another disastrous coalition with the Tories.ldquoIt seems the LibDems are happy to jump back into bed with the extreme right Tory party but not work with us to ensure that the livelihoods of citizens across the UK are not destroyed by a disastrous Brexit.Neil Gray A Scottish Labour spokesman said: ldquoOnly Labour will ensure no-deal is avoided. The only way to get a Labour government is to vote Labour. We will not be doing deals with the SNP, LibDems or anyone . We are fighting for a Labour Government, no s and no buts.Tory party chairman James Cleverly insisted the Conservatives would not ldquoinitiate a general election. Asked on Skyrsquos Sophy Ridge On Sundaythere will be a general election, Mr Cleverly said: ldquoThere isnrsquot. We are not going to initiate a general election.It was also reported thatMr Johnson was forced into an election by a no-confidence vote in September, he could hold it on October  or later, allowing a no-deal Brexit by default.The Sundaysaid the PMrsquos top aide, Dominic Cummings, had told colleagues it was now too late for MPs to use a no-confidence vote to block Brexit.ldquoIf there is a no-confidence vote in September or October, wersquoll call an election for after October  and leave anyway, Mr Cummings said.However, rebel Tory MP Dominic Grieve said Mr Cummings was a ldquomaster of misinformation and losing a no-confidence vote created a -day window to form a new government.Labour MP Jonathan Ashworth also rejected Mr Cummingsrsquos analysis.ldquoThere will be opportunities for us when parliament s in September to stop no deal, he told Sky.The Cabinet manual also says that, during an election campaign, the government should not take decisions which would bind its successor.This would seem to rule out Mr Johnson engineering a no-deal exit.However, the Sunday Times reported the PM might carry on regardless, as much of the law in this area is untested, and only he can ask the EU to postpone Brexit or revoke Article .Ian Blackford, the SNP Westminster leader, yesterday asked all opposition parties bar the DUP to a cross-party summit on how to avoid a no-deal Brexit.He said: ldquoLetrsquos see what happens in September, he said. ldquoBecause the government will have to bring forward appropriate legislation to prepare for this Brexit no-deal exit that they want. And we will use all the means available to us, working across the parties ndash because we know there are plenty of Tory MPs who want to block no deal as well, particularly a lot of those who Boris Johnson, perhaps rather foolishly in retrospect, sacked from the cabinet two weeks ago.ldquoWersquore working with MPs across the House of Commons, and we will work to stop no deal.Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay said the leaders of the EU should give their chief negotiator a free hand or a no-deal Brexit was ldquocoming down the tracks.Brexit secretary Stephen Barclay In a newspaper article, Mr Barclay said Michel Barnier had to be given the latitude to rewrite the withdrawal agreement and remove the ldquoanti-democratic Irish backstop.Mr Barclay said the EU negotiator, who called abolishing the backstop ldquounacceptable, told him last week he was bound by instructions from the European Commission and EU leaders.Mr Barclay said ldquopolitical realities had changed, with  per cent of MEPs newly elected in May, and Mr Johnson in Downing Street vowing to deliver Brexit ldquodo or die in three months.He wrote: ldquoSuch a fundamental sht illustrates the need for a change of approach Mr Barnier needs to urge EU leaders to consider thisthey too want an agreement, to enable him to negotiate in a way that finds common ground with the UK. Otherwise, no-deal is coming down the tracks.Meanwhile, His message was undermined by an Education Department memo was leaked warning that schools might close, food could run short and exams may be disrupted by no-deal, particularly in Kent because of travel chaos at ports.Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said the SNP must ringfence the poundm in Barnett consequential for NHS Scotland, something Scottish ministers already do.

title: mark-smith-know-gay-professional-footballers-scotland-tried-convince-one-go-public-stopping-fans
story: You may also have seen the tweets of someone called ldquothe gay footballer who said he was about to go public. But donrsquot think any of this means wersquore about to see an openly gay star in the menrsquos game, or that football is on the verge of a breakthrough. Wersquore not and it isnrsquot. Menrsquos football still has a serious problem with sex and sexuality.I know this because Irsquove dealt with some of the people involved. A while ago, I spent several months, through a friend, trying to convince a player with a Scottish premiership side to speak to me publicly about his sexuality. He appeared to be open to persuasion, but in the end he decided it just wasnrsquot worth the heartache.What was particularly interesting is that the playerrsquos team-mates and other players, the managers, and other staff, including my friend, all knew about his sexuality and were fine with it. Which leaves only one reason not to go public: the fans.:What its like to be a gay football fan in Scotland in Donrsquot misunderstand what Irsquom saying here: Irsquom not suggesting everyone in football management is cool with being gay ndash even now, most managers are older, working-class men who are often the last to adapt to changing social attitudes. Irsquove also spoken to a former youth coach who said he was told by a premiership side he couldnrsquot be employed with them because of his sexuality.However, itrsquos obvious that, on the whole, attitudes to sexuality within football have been changing and players and staff are generally much more open on the subject .The reaction of players has also possibly always been exaggerated. Karren Brady, the former boss of Birmingham City, said the other day that her husband, Paul Peschisolido, had played with Justin Fashanu in the s and no one in the dressing room had a problem with him being gay.The point is that, whether Karren Brady is right or not about the s, attitudes in the game have been improving, just as they have in society generally. There are several clubs in the UK now that have gay players who are honest about their sexuality within the team and even take their partners to club events ndash they are just not open about it in public.The Celtic captain Scott Brown was also clearly being honest when he said he would be supportive to a team-mate who was gay. And even players at Millwallhave said it doesnrsquot mattera team-mate is gay. As one football commentator put it to me: other players wouldnrsquot give a ****.:English menrsquos game could soon have its first openly gay professional playerThe problem is that some fans are unlikely to feel the same way. Recently, my colleague Neil Cameron spoke to one of the players with the LGBT team HotScots FC, Craig Anderson, who said there have been times when the homophobic abuse hersquos heard at games has made him wonder whether football is the game for him. Irsquove also spoken to some of the HotScots players myself and they pretty much all say the same thing: in the changing room, sexuality is not a problem out in the stadium among some of the fans, it still is.Itrsquos interesting to speculate on what the reasons for this might be. One theory that amuses me is that the fans who are most vocal with homophobic abuse are trying to come to terms with the fact they love a game that idolises physically fit young men. A game like football in which the players are so uninhibited about kissing and touching each other should be the least homophobic of all, but some male fans may struggle with that, so they shout about poofs and queers to try to prove to the rest of us that theyrsquore not interested in the sight of players kissing and hugging other men. But wersquore on to them. We know they secretly love it.The idea that homophobia in football might be a problem with specic types of men rather than fans more generally is also borne out by the recent womenrsquos world cup. Menrsquos professional football has virtually no openly gay players, but the womenrsquos game is the opposite ndash it is full of out gay women at the highest level.And even the homophobia the female players experience confirms this is really a male problem wersquore talking about: some fans like to assume all female players are lesbians because they think football is essentially a manrsquos sport and any woman who wants to play it must ldquowant to be a man.Unfortunately, there is only one way to tackle this. Players can, and should, do positive interviews like the one Scott Brown did at the weekend. Football clubs can also prove how open they are, as Partick Thistle did recently with their kit inspired by the LGBT rainbow flag. But sadly, none of it will be enough to change the attitude of fans ndash that will only happen when the first British professional player in the premier league goes public about his sexuality.Are we getting closer to that point  You might think the tweets from ldquothe gay footballer prove we are. The tweeter said he was a professional player and would go public at the end of July. However, he then deleted the account which must obviously raise doubts about its authenticity. It also disappointed a lot of football fans because they know the game needs its first openly gay player.Whoever that player ends up being, he will definitely get abuse and there will be a backlash from some fans, and possibly players on other teams. But until someone openly challenges the homophobia in football by being openly gay, the homophobia will not go away.I realise thatrsquos a lot for one person to take on and he will have to be a pretty extraordinary person. But after it has happened, others will follow. Gay players will then become more visible. They will then be just part of the team. And finally homophobia in football will become socially unacceptable.It will also become a little ridiculous. Why would you scream abuse at someone whorsquos good  Why would you hate someone whorsquos brilliant at the game you love

title: number-scottish-firms-going-rises-46-six-months
story: Professional services firm KPMG said economic volatility is behind the trend, with Brexit creating uncertainty for businesses.The KPMG report comes a matter of weeks after the latest Scottish Chambers of CommerceQuarterly Economic Indicator said theeconomy is ldquorunning on fumes as the protracted uncertainty overBrexitcontinues to cause firms to put business investment on hold.A majority of firms were continuing to see cost rises because of skills shortages and sterling weakness sparked by the Brexit vote three years ago, which has pushed up the price of raw materials.KPMG advised Scottish businesses to plan for worst-case scenarios and be fiscally cautious.The firm said there were  corporate insolvency appointments between January and June, up from  in the previous six months.Of the  cases, the vast majorityinvolved a company liquidation, while  were administration and receivership appointments.:Fe manufacturer Havelock failed with office deal unresolvedThe number of insolvencies in the quarter ending June  is similar to that of the same period the previous year.Blair Nimmo, KPMG head of restructuring, said: "While there is clearly a trend towards an increase in corporate insolvencies, there are some signs of resilience."The last quarter has remained far more static and a number of industries are taking proactive measures to put themselves on a more stable financial footing, including retailers, hoping corporate voluntary arrangement proposals could head off the prospect of administration."The ongoing Brexit discussions and change of Prime Minister and Cabinet have undoubtedly create a climate of uncertainty but there are wider challenges at play, creating a toxic mix of issues for businesses going through a period of distress."He added: "The best approach for any business in Scotland right now is to maintain a fiscally cautious approach, ensuring you maximise reserves, proactively and regularly review contingency plans and - ultimately - plan for any worst case scenarios.:lsquoSerious implicationsrsquo for Scotland from threat to immigration, Fraser of Allander warns"A number of challenges could be on the horizon, but with a resilient, focused approach, including taking appropriate advice at an early stage, Scotlands business community can continue to grow sustainably in the long-term."The Scottish Chambers of CommerceQuarterly Economic Indicator, published last monthlaidbare the ldquochaos caused by Brexit ldquodithering by the UKGovernment, which has so far failed to secure the support ofParliamentfor proposals rubber-stamping the departure from the EU.

title: majority-now-want-scottish-independence-says-phenomenal-new-poll
story: The study by Lord Ashcroft Polls, published in the Holyrood Magazine, wasconducted days after new Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited Scotlandand shows the majority want a second referendum by .It puts support for independence at  per cent for and  per cent against.:Boris Johnson appears unsure of number of Scottish independence votesWhen those who did not know how they would vote, or said they would not vote, are removed, support for independence rises to % for, % against.Andone in five Better Togethervoters in the referendum said they would switch to vote forindependence.Lord Ashcroft said it was thefirstlead for independence in a published poll since an Ipsos MORI survey in March , and the biggest lead since a spate of polls in June , shortly after the UK voted to leave the EU.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, in relaying the "phenomenal" findings on social media said that "attempts by the Tories to block Scotlandrsquos right to choose our own future are undemocratic and unsustainable".When asked what the outcome would bethere was a new referendum on Scottish independence, %Scotsthought it would lead to a break from the Union. That dropped to around one in three of those who voted Better Together in the  independence referendum.If there were a new referendum on Scottish independence, what do you think the outcome would be  pic pnuBeKiDSMs Sturgeon added: ldquoThis is a phenomenal poll for the independence movement mdash showing that more and more people think itrsquos time that Scotland took our own decisions and shaped our own future as a fair, prosperous, outward-looking nation.ldquoIndependence means getting governments people in Scotland vote for and that will act in our interests. That stands in stark contrast to recent experience of UK governments incapable or unwilling to act with those interests in mind.:Splits over Indyref set to hamper bid to halt a hard BrexitldquoMeanwhile, the case for independence grows stronger by the day. ldquoA broken Westminster system means Scotland is being dragged towards a No Deal Brexit, regardless of the heavy price wersquoll pay for lost jobs and lower living standards. That project is being led by Boris Johnson mdash a Prime Minister Scotland didnrsquot elect and who has no mandate to tear Scotland out of Europe with all the damage that will entail.ldquoThe Scottish Government, by contrast, has a very clear mandate from the people of Scotland mdash to give them the choice of a better future with independence. ldquoIt would be a democratic outrage for any Tory government to deny that, and this poll shows such an anti-democratic position is completely unsustainable.The online poll questioned , adults in Scotland between July  and August .The poll found that %agreedthere should be another referendum on Scottish independence within the next two years.Nearly two in three thought Brexit would make it more likely that Scotland will become independent in the foreseeable future with % believing it was much more likely.More than half ofNo voters in the  referendum thoughtthis is the case, with % of them saying it makes independence much more likely.And % would rather see a Labour government led by Jeremy Corbyn than a Conservative administration run by Boris Johnson.Majority of people in Scotland now want #Indyref and would vote for independence, according to new poll in @HolyroodDaily - attempts by the Tories to block Scotlandrsquos right to choose our own future are undemocratic and unsustainable. https:t.co PftesilCMResponding to the poll, Scottish Greens Co- Leader Patrick Harvie MSP added: "Its time that the people of Scotland were given a choice over their future."We didnt vote for Brexit, we didnt vote for a Tory government and Im certain that given the choice we wouldnt have voted for Boris Johnson either, yet we are being dragged along with the ever-increasing Brexit catastrophe, so its no wonder that a majority of Scots now recognise the need for us to make an exit from Boris Johnsons Brexit Britain."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Thousands take part in march in support of Scottish independence in Ayr","description": "Thousands take part in march in support of Scottish independence in Ayr","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs kDRktGq-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests kDRktGq.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": "We already have a mandate to hold an independence referendum, yet the Tory Government has threatened to block a request. This would be an affront to democracy and is wholly untenable in the face of public support for a vote."Its time for Scotland to retake our place as an independent European nation."

title: major-road-works-m8-commence-next-month
story: Essential concrete repairs, installation of combined drainage, waterproofing, central barrier replacement, joint replacement and carriageway surfacing work will take place on the M at Junction , East Whitburn Bridges from Monday th September until Monday th December .The work is set to be carried outcontinuously, in two phases, over twelve weeks.The works, which will cost around pound, aims to improvethe condition of the structures and carriageway, and reducing the need for more extensive maintenance in the future.Amey claims that once carried out, the workwill benefit around , vehicles using this section of the M each day.Throughout the duration of the works, recovery vehicles will be on-site to assist with potential breakdowns and the speed limit through the works will be reduced to mph. The anticipated maximum delays to the M mainline traffic is estimated at less than  minutes across both phases.:Busy section of Glasgow M partial closed after lorry overturns in roadScheme mobilisation will take place from Monday th September until Friday th September  and requires the closure of both the M eastbound and westbound carriageways between the hours of pm and am each night.The mobilisation period is required to remove existing road markings in preparation of traffic management and install mobile iable message signage.During this mobilisation work, westbound traffic will be instructed to exit the M via Junction a to join the A northbound towards Boghall Roundabout.At the roundabout, traffic will take the first exit onto the A southbound and at Boghead Roundabout will take the third exit to join the A.Traffic will continue straight through Whitdale Roundabout and will take the first right turn onto the B. At Heartlands Industrial Estate Roundabout, traffic will take the third exit and follow signage to rejoin the M westbound via Junction a.Eastbound traffic will follow the same ersion route but in the opposite direction.Phase one of the works will be carried out from Friday th September until Wednesday rd October  with -hour traffic management in operation.The M eastbound mainline carriageway at Junction  will be closed with traffic running on hard shoulder and slip road while on the westbound mainline carriageway lane one will remain open to traffic as will the slip road.Temporary traffic signals will be in place at the bottom of each slip road and on the A roundabout.:M reopened following early morning crashBetween Wednesday rd October and Sunday th October  there will be further overnight closures of both the M Junction  eastbound and westbound carriageways from pm until am, each night.Phase two of the works will be carried out under -hour traffic management from Sunday th October until Monday th December .There will be a full closure of the eastbound carriageway with traffic erted via slip roads and a contraflow onto lane two of the westbound carriageway. Westbound traffic will continue on lane one, and the slip roads at M Junction .As the scheme progresses, the traffic management layout will switch such that westbound traffic will be erted using slip roads and a contraflow onto lane two of the eastbound carriageway. Eastbound traffic will run on lane one, and the slip roads at M Junction .
